name: methyl_4-phenylbenzoate
source: Beilstein F. K.; Beilsteins Handbuch der Organischen Chemie. Springer; Berlin; 1972.
Reason: 4-phenylbenzoate has a melting point of around 100°C due to the presence of a phenyl group, which increases the melting point due to its ability to enhance π-π interactions and overall molecular rigidity. The methyl group can also contribute to the melting point, but to a lesser extent. The methyl group introduces a rigid structure, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and increase the melting point by approximately +5°C.
